value.ImpactDescription: Users may have been unable to access your organization.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Organization inaccessible 

User Impact: Users may be unable to access your organization

We are investigating an issue in which some users are experiencing an inability to access your organization. Our next update will be provided within 30 minutes.

Title: Organization inaccessible

User Impact: Users may be unable to access your organization

Current Status: After our investigation, we determined that your organization has become inaccessible following a recent deployment. We are currently monitoring telemetry to identify the source of this issue.
 
Incident Start Time: Sunday, November 17, 2019, at 3:30 AM UTC
 
Next Update: Sunday, November 17, 2019, at 7:30 AM UTC to allow time to gather telemetry.
A post-incident report has been published.

Title: Organization inaccessible

User Impact: Users may have been unable to access your organization.

Final Status: We isolated a code misconfiguration in your recent deployment. We have reconfigured the code, restoring access to your production organization. 
 
Incident Start Time: Sunday, November 17, 2019, at 3:30 AM UTC

Incident End Time: Sunday, November 17, 2019, at 5:58 AM UTC

Preliminary Root Cause: A code misconfiguration in a recent deployment caused a loss of access to your production environment.

Next Steps: We're reviewing our standard service update procedures to avoid similar impact in the future.

A post-incident report (PIR) will be published within five days.
A post-incident report has been published.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Discovery service inaccessible

User Impact: Users may not be able to access the Discovery service within their Dynamics 365 organization.

We are investigating an issue in which some users are unable to utilize the Discovery service within their Dynamics 365 organization. Our next update will be provided within 30 minutes.

Title: Discovery service inaccessible

User Impact: Users may not be able to access the Discovery Service within their Dynamics 365 organization.

Current Status: After our investigation, we identified that a misconfiguration within a recent deployment may be preventing some users from accessing the Discovery service. We are performing a rollback to restore service.
 
Incident Start Time: Wednesday, November 20, 2019, at 4:01 AM UTC
 
Next Update: Wednesday, November 20, 2019, at 11:00 AM UTC, to allow time for the rollback to complete.

Title: Discovery service inaccessible

User Impact: Users may have been unable to access the Discovery service within their Dynamics 365 organization.

Final Status: After performing the rollback, we identified a misconfigured certificate. We applied the necessary configuration changes and verified through telemetry that full functionality has been restored.

Incident Start Time: Wednesday, November 20, 2019, at 4:01 AM UTC
 
Incident Start Time: Wednesday, November 20, 2019, at 9:25 AM UTC
 
Preliminary Root Cause: A misconfigured certificate prevented Discovery service access.
 
Next Steps: We're analyzing performance data and trends on the affected systems to prevent this problem from happening again.
 
This is the final update on the incident.

value.ImpactDescription: Dynamics 365 for Marketing users may be unable to utilize some features within Dynamics 365 for Marketing.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Performance degradation

User Impact: Dynamics 365 for Marketing users may be unable to utilize some features within Dynamics 365 for Marketing.

We are investigating an issue in which some users are experiencing difficulties accessing some features of Dynamics 365 for Marketing within their organization. Our next update will be provided within 30 minutes.

Title: Performance degradation

User Impact: Dynamics 365 for Marketing users may be unable to utilize some features within Dynamics 365 for Marketing.

More Info: The issue is intermittent, and users may be able to utilize the affected features of Dynamics 365 for Marketing by retrying.
 
Current Status: After our investigation, we determined that this issue has been caused by an Azure service outage. A fix is currently being rolled out for the outage which will restore full functionality to Dynamics 365 for Marketing.
 
Incident Start Time: Sunday, November 24, 2019, at 10:21 AM UTC
 
Next Update: Sunday, November 24, 2019, at 2:00 PM UTC, to allow time for the fix to be deployed.

Title: Performance degradation

User Impact: Dynamics 365 for Marketing users may be unable to utilize some features within Dynamics 365 for Marketing.

More Info: The issue was intermittent, and users may have been able to utilize the affected features of Dynamics 365 for Marketing by retrying.
 
Final Status: After our investigation, we determined this issue was related to an Azure service outage. A fix has been deployed and we have confirmed via telemetry that full functionality has been restored. Actions attempted during this time may be delayed.
 
Incident Start Time: Sunday, November 24, 2019, at 7:25 AM UTC
 
Incident End Time: Sunday, November 24, 2019, at 11:10 AM UTC
 
Preliminary Root Cause: An Azure service outage prevented some features of Dynamics 365 for Marketing from processing requests successfully.
 
Next Steps: We're analyzing performance data and trends on the affected systems to prevent this problem from happening again.
 
This is the final update on the incident.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Timeline errors

User Impact: Users may receive an error when using their Timeline.

We are investigating an issue in which some users are experiencing problems with Timeline errors. Our next update will be provided within 30 minutes.

Title: Record timeline errors

User Impact: Users may receive an error when using the Timeline function within records.

More Info: Users may be unable to use the Timeline function within records and receive the following error message when attempting to do so: “An unexpected error occurred”.

Current Status: Our investigation has determined that timelines within records are not functioning correctly. This is due to a code misconfiguration, and we are developing a fix to address the issue.
 
Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC
 
Next Update: Monday, November 25, 2019, at 4:00 AM UTC to allow time for additional investigation.

Title: Record timeline errors

User Impact: Users may receive an error when using the Timeline function within records.

More Info: Users may be unable to use the Timeline function within records and receive the following error message when attempting to do so: “An unexpected error occurred”.

Current Status: We are continuing to develop, test and validate a code fix to address the current misconfiguration.
 
Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC
 
Next Update: Monday, November 25, 2019, at 7:00 AM UTC to allow time to develop the code fix.

Title: Record timeline errors

User Impact: Users may receive an error when using the Timeline function within records.

More Info: Users may be unable to use the Timeline function within records and receive the following error message when attempting to do so: “An unexpected error occurred”.

Current Status: Testing and validation of a permanent fix for this issue is ongoing. In parallel, we have created and validated a script that can be applied to resolve this issue. If you are experiencing this issue, please contact support to receive this script.
 
Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC
 
Next Update: Monday, November 25, 2019, at 9:00 AM UTC to allow time to develop the code fix.

Title: Record timeline errors

User Impact: Users may receive an error when using the Timeline function within records.

More Info: Users may be unable to use the Timeline function within records and receive the following error message when attempting to do so: “An unexpected error occurred”.

Current Status: We are continuing to test and validate a permanent fix for this issue. In parallel, we have created and validated a script that can be applied to resolve this issue. If you are experiencing this issue, please contact support to receive this script.
 
Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC
 
Next Update: Monday, November 25, 2019, at 2:00 PM UTC to allow time to develop the code fix.

Title: Record timeline errors

User Impact: Users may receive an error when using the Timeline function within records.

More Info: Users may be unable to use the Timeline function within records and receive the following error message when attempting to do so: “An unexpected error occurred”. If your organization is still receiving this error during this deployment period, we have created and validated a script that can be applied to resolve this issue immediately by contacting customer support.

Current Status: A permanent fix has been developed and tested and is in the process of being deployed to your organization.
 
Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC
 
Next Update: Monday, November 25, 2019, at 8:30 PM UTC to allow time for the deployment to be completed.

Title: Timeline control errors

User Impact: Users may encounter an error when using the timeline control within records.

More Info: Users may receive the error message: "An unexpected error occurred".

As we continue to deploy the mitigating fix, some of your organizations' functionality may be restored.

If your users are still encountering an error when using the timeline control within records, please contact customer support so that we can apply a mitigating script to resolve this issue.

Current Status: We are continuing to monitor the progress of the fix deployment.

Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC

Next Update: Tuesday, November 26, 2019, at 9:00 PM UTC, to allow time for the deployment to be completed.

Title: Timeline control errors

User Impact: Users may encounter an error when using the timeline control within records.

More Info: Users may receive the error message: "An unexpected error occurred".

As we continue to deploy the mitigating fix, some of your organizations' functionality may be restored.

If your users are still encountering an error when using the timeline control within records, please contact customer support so that we can apply a mitigating script to resolve this issue.

Current Status: We are continuing to monitor the progress of the fix deployment. As this is expected to take an extended period of time, we will provide updates as new information becomes available or by the time listed below.

Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC

Next Update: Wednesday, November 27, 2019, at 9:00 PM UTC, to allow time for the deployment to be completed.

Title: Timeline control errors

User Impact: Users may encounter an error when using the timeline control within records.

More Info: Users may receive the error message: "An unexpected error occurred".

As we continue to deploy the mitigating fix, some of your organizations' functionality may be restored.

If your users are still encountering an error when using the timeline control within records, please contact customer support so that we can apply a mitigating script to resolve this issue.

Current Status: The fix deployment is in progress and is expected to take an extended period of time. We will provide updates as new information becomes available or by the time listed below.

Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC

Next Update: Monday, December 2, 2019, at 9:00 PM UTC, to allow time for the deployment to be completed.

Title: Timeline control errors

User Impact: Users may have encountered an error when using the timeline control within records.

Final Status: Deployment of the fix has successfully completed, restoring full functionality. 

Incident Start Time: Saturday, November 23, 2019, at 10:59 PM UTC

Incident End Time: Saturday, November 30, 2019 at 7:00 AM UTC

Next Steps: We’re reviewing our code for improved performance and potential automated recovery options to reduce or avoid similar issues in the future.

This is the final update on the incident.
A post-incident report has been published.

value.ImpactDescription: Users may have experienced that some edits in parent cases were not cascading to child cases.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Parent not cascading 

User Impact: Users may experience some edits in parent cases are not cascading to child cases.

We are investigating an issue in which some edits in parent cases are not cascading to child cases. Our next update will be provided within 30 minutes.

Title: Parent record owner changes not cascading to child records

User Impact: Users may experience some edits in parent cases are not cascading to child cases.

Current Status: After our investigation, we have determined that when a user opens a parent record and changes the assigned owner, this change is not cascaded to the child records. We are isolating the issue and determining troubleshooting steps.
 
Incident Start Time: Thursday, December 12th, 2019, at 12:32 AM UTC
 
Next Update: Friday, December 13th, 2019, at 8:00 AM UTC, to allow additional time to identify the root cause and potential troubleshooting steps.

Title: Parent record owner changes not cascading to child records

User Impact: Users may experience some edits in parent cases are not cascading to child cases.

Current Status: We have isolated the issue to a code misconfiguration. A code fix is currently being developed and will be deployed when ready.
 
Incident Start Time: Thursday, December 12th, 2019, at 12:32 AM UTC
 
Next Update: Friday, December 13th, 2019, at 5:00 PM UTC, to allow time to develop and test the code fix.

Title: Parent record owner changes not cascading to child records

User Impact: Users may experience some edits in parent cases are not cascading to child cases.

Current Status: We have developed the code fix for this issue and are developing a schedule to deploy it to your organization.

Incident Start Time: Thursday, December 12th, 2019, at 12:32 AM UTC

Next Update: Friday, December 13th, 2019, at 8:00 PM UTC, to allow time to deploy the code fix.

Title: Parent record owner changes not cascading to child records

User Impact: Users may have experienced that some edits in parent cases were not cascading to child cases.

Final Status: The code fix has been deployed successfully, and we validated via telemetry review that parent case cascading functionality has been restored.

Incident Start Time: Thursday, December 12th, 2019, at 12:32 AM UTC

Incident End Time: Friday, December 13th, 2019, at 5:17 PM UTC

Preliminary Root Cause: A code misconfiguration impacted parent record cascading functionality. 

Next Steps: We're analyzing performance data and trends on the affected systems to prevent this problem from happening again.

This is the final update on the incident.

value.ImpactDescription: Admins were unable to initiate new or view status of existing migration jobs in the Exchange admin center (EAC).

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Can't complete migrations

User Impact: Admins are unable to initiate new or view status of existing migration jobs in the Exchange admin center (EAC).

More info: This issue is specific to admins attempting to migrate Gmail and Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) accounts to Exchange Online using the EAC, or admins migrating via Outlook Anywhere.

As a workaround, admins may be able to complete migrations using PowerShell. For instructions, please reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/powershell/use-powershell-for-email-migration-to-office-365.

We'd like to get your feedback on the workaround we provided. From a non-mobile device, please rate this post and submit it in the textbox.

Current status: We've identified a code issue causing migrations to fail when admins attempt to migrate Gmail and Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) accounts to Exchange Online using the EAC, or admins migrating via Outlook Anywhere. Additionally, viewing the status of existing migration jobs in the EAC may be impacted. We're working to validate and deploy a code fix for this issue to restore functionality.

Scope of impact: Impact is specific to admins attempting to migrate users via EAC or Outlook Anywhere.

Next update by: Friday, December 13, 2019, at 11:00 PM UTC

Title: Can't complete migrations

User Impact: Admins are unable to initiate new or view status of existing migration jobs in the Exchange admin center (EAC).

More info: This issue is specific to admins attempting to migrate Gmail and Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) accounts to Exchange Online using the EAC, or admins migrating via Outlook Anywhere.

As a workaround, admins may be able to complete migrations using PowerShell. For instructions, please reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/powershell/use-powershell-for-email-migration-to-office-365.

We'd like to get your feedback on the workaround we provided. From a non-mobile device, please rate this post and submit it in the textbox.

Current status: We've validated the code fix and deployment is scheduled to begin on Saturday, December 14, 2019. We expect that this fix will take up to four days to fully saturate the affected environments and we'll provide updates during the deployment process.

Scope of impact: Impact is specific to admins attempting to migrate users via EAC or Outlook Anywhere.

Root cause: A recent update to the Exchange admin center (EAC) introduced a code issue, causing migrations to fail when admins attempt to migrate Gmail and Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) accounts to Exchange Online using the EAC, or admins migrating via Outlook Anywhere.

Next update by: Monday, December 16, 2019, at 11:00 PM UTC

Title: Can't complete migrations

User Impact: Admins were unable to initiate new or view status of existing migration jobs in the Exchange admin center (EAC).

More info: This issue was specific to admins attempting to migrate Gmail and Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) accounts to Exchange Online using the EAC, or admins migrating via Outlook Anywhere.

As a workaround, admins may have been able to complete migrations using PowerShell. For instructions, please reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/powershell/use-powershell-for-email-migration-to-office-365.

We'd like to get your feedback on the workaround we provided. From a non-mobile device, please rate this post and submit it in the textbox.

Final status: The code fix has completely saturated the majority of the service environment and internal testing confirms that this has remediated impact.

Scope of impact: Impact was specific to admins attempting to migrate users via EAC or Outlook Anywhere.

Start time: Thursday, December 12, 2019, at 6:51 PM UTC

End time: Monday, December 16, 2019, at 10:37 PM UTC

Root cause: A recent update to the Exchange admin center (EAC) introduced a code issue, causing migrations to fail when admins attempt to migrate Gmail and Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) accounts to Exchange Online using the EAC, or admins migrating via Outlook Anywhere.

Next steps:
-We will continue to monitor deployment and review provisioning procedure to help prevent similar issues from reoccurring the future.

This is the final update for the event.

value.ImpactDescription: Users may intermittently experience latency or be unable to add accounts in the Outlook mobile app.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Outlook mobile latency and account problems

User Impact: Users may intermittently experience latency, or be unable to add accounts in the Outlook mobile app.

More info: The problem with adding accounts is limited to new users.

Current status: We're analyzing available diagnostic data, such as correlation IDs and error logs, to isolate the cause of this issue and determine our next steps.

Scope of impact: The problem may affect new users attempting to add accounts, and all users may experience latency accessing the Exchange Online service from the Outlook mobile app.

Next update by: Saturday, December 14, 2019, at 12:30 AM UTC

Title: Outlook mobile latency and account problems

User Impact: Users may intermittently experience latency, or be unable to add accounts in the Outlook mobile app.

More info: The problem with adding accounts is mostly limited to new users adding Exchange on-premises accounts. Additionally, tenant admins may notice their on-premises server fails to keep up with requests and times out.

Current status: After our analysis of the diagnostics, we're focusing our investigation on an issue with our Exchange ActiveSync (EAS) service's interaction with the on-premises infrastructure. 

Scope of impact: The problem may affect new users attempting to add accounts, and all users may experience latency accessing the Exchange Online service from the Outlook mobile app. 

Next update by: Sunday, December 15, 2019, at 6:30 PM UTC

Title: Outlook mobile latency and account problems

User Impact: Users may intermittently experience latency or are unable to add accounts in the Microsoft Outlook mobile app.

More info: The problem with adding accounts is mostly limited to new users adding Exchange on-premises accounts. Additionally, tenant admins may notice their on-premises server fails to keep up with requests and times out. 

Current status: We're analyzing a subset of Exchange Online code associated with our Exchange ActiveSync (EAS) service's interaction with on-premises infrastructure to determine our next troubleshooting steps for remediating impact. 

Scope of impact: Your organization is affected by this event. This issue may affect any Unmanaged OnPrem Cloud Cache (U-OPCC) users accessing their mailbox via the Microsoft Outlook mobile app. 

Next update by: Monday, December 16, 2019, at 6:00 PM UTC

Title: Outlook mobile latency and account problems

User Impact: Users may intermittently experience latency or are unable to add accounts in the Microsoft Outlook mobile app.

More info: The problem with adding accounts is mostly limited to new users adding Exchange on-premises accounts. Additionally, tenant admins may notice their on-premises server fails to keep up with requests and times out.

Current status: We're continuing to analyze the aforementioned Exchange Online code as we test potential solutions for mitigation.

Scope of impact: Your organization is affected by this event. This issue may affect any Unmanaged OnPrem Cloud Cache (U-OPCC) users accessing their mailbox via the Outlook mobile app.

Next update by: Monday, December 16, 2019, at 8:30 PM UTC

Title: Outlook mobile latency and account problems

User Impact: Users may intermittently experience latency or be unable to add accounts in the Outlook mobile app.

More info: The problem with adding accounts is mostly limited to new users adding Exchange on-premises accounts. Additionally, tenant admins may notice their on-premises server fails to keep up with requests and times out.

Current status: We've determined that an unusually large amount of data syncing between user Outlook mobile apps and Exchange Online is resulting in queued changes, leading to latency in adding accounts. We've identified a setting change to reduce client-side check-ins and item syncing and are currently developing a fix deployment to update this setting and mitigate impact. We'll provide a better estimate to full deployment of this fix once it has been fully tested and scheduled. In parallel, we're looking into a longer-term solution that would allow admins to exclude downloading attachments to Outlook Mobile when devices for new users adding Exchange on-premises accounts are in an initial sync period to ease server demand.

Scope of impact: This issue may affect any Unmanaged OnPrem Cloud Cache (U-OPCC) users accessing their mailbox via the Outlook mobile app.

Root cause: An unusually large amount of data syncing between user Outlook mobile apps and Exchange Online is resulting in queued changes, leading to latency in adding accounts.

Next update by: Tuesday, December 17, 2019, at 9:00 PM UTC

User Impact: Users may be unable to initiate chat messages, audio calls, or video calls to specific external federated users.

More info: This affects calls and messages to a specific federated domain.

Current status: We're investigating a potential issue and checking for impact to your organization. We'll provide an update within 30 minutes.

Scope of impact: Your organization is affected by this event, and this issue may impact any user attempting to send messages or make calls to specific external federated users.

User Impact: Users may be unable to initiate chat messages, audio calls, or video calls to specific external federated users.

More info: This affects calls and messages to a specific federated domain.

Current status: We're collecting log data from a portion of infrastructure that facilitates federated user interactions and analyzing provided client logs to determine the source of the issue.

Scope of impact: Your organization is affected by this event, and this issue may impact any user attempting to send messages or make calls to specific external federated users.

Next update by: Wednesday, December 4, 2019, at 8:30 PM UTC

Title: Can't send messages or make calls to specific federated users

User Impact: Users may be unable to initiate chat messages, audio calls, or video calls to specific external federated users.

More info: This affects calls and messages to a specific federated domain. 

Current status: The federation logs have been inconclusive regarding the call data provided by your organization. We're reviewing relevant code to determine where the issue is occurring and the underlying cause. 

Scope of impact: Your organization is affected by this event, and this issue may impact any user attempting to send messages or make calls to specific external federated users. 

Next update by: Wednesday, December 4, 2019, at 10:00 PM UTC

Title: Can't send messages or make calls to specific federated users

User Impact: Users may be unable to initiate chat messages, audio calls, or video calls to specific external federated users.

More info: This event affects tenants who have users hosted in Skype for Business and on-premises with the same domain, with name space set to False, and are making federation calls to federated users on-premises. This does not affect tenants who are strictly hosted in Skype for Business, nor users who have domain name space set to True. 

Current status: We've determined that an active code deployment intended to address federation routing issues resulted in impact. We’ve halted the deployment and are developing a code change to revert the portion of the update that’s resulting in impact. 

Scope of impact: This issue may potentially affect a subset of your on-premises users attempting to call federated on-premises users only. 

Start time: Sunday, December 1, 2019, at 4:00 AM UTC 

Root cause: A recent code update intended to address federation routing issues resulted in impact to users in a specific federation configuration.

Title: Can't send messages or make calls to specific federated users

User Impact: Users may be unable to initiate chat messages, audio calls, or video calls to specific external federated users.

More info: This event affects tenants who have users hosted in Skype for Business and on-premises with the same domain, with name space set to False, and are making federation calls to federated users on-premises. This does not affect tenants who are strictly hosted in Skype for Business, nor users who have domain name space set to True. 

Current status: We've validated the fix in our internal environment and expect deployment of the fix to affected environments to complete by Monday, January 6, 2020. We'll provide updates on deployment status as they become available. 

Scope of impact: This issue may potentially affect a limited number of your on-premises users attempting to call federated on-premises users only. 

Start time: Sunday, December 1, 2019, at 4:00 AM UTC 

Root cause: A recent code update intended to address federation routing issues resulted in impact to users in a specific federation configuration. 

Next update by: Friday, December 27, 2019, at 11:00 PM UTC

value.Title: Can't send messages or make calls to specific federated users

value.ImpactDescription: Users may be unable to call numbers with a +65 country code in Skype for Business and from Skype conference bridges.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Can't call +65 country code

User Impact: Users may be unable to call numbers with a +65 country code in Skype for Business and from Skype conference bridges. 

Current status: We're investigating a potential issue with the Skype for Business service. We'll provide an update within 30 minutes.

Scope of impact: This issue may affect any users attempting to call numbers with a +65 country code.

Title: Can't call +65 country code

User Impact: Users may be unable to call numbers with a +65 country code in Skype for Business and from Skype conference bridges. 

Current status: We're reviewing examples of calls ended via timeouts and are analyzing the specific call routes taken to determine our next troubleshooting steps.

Scope of impact: This issue may affect any users attempting to call numbers with a +65 country code.

Next update by: Friday, December 13, 2019, at 9:30 PM UTC

Title: Can't call +65 country code

User Impact: Users may have been unable to call numbers with a +65 country code in Skype for Business and from Skype conference bridges. 

Final status: We've determined that a common, intermediate carrier in-route for calls to +65 was in a degraded state. This carrier route has been removed and calls rerouted through alternate infrastructure. After testing, we've confirmed that impact is mitigated.

Scope of impact: This issue may have affected any users attempting to call numbers with a +65 country code.

Start time: Monday, December 9, 2019, at 2:00 AM UTC

End time: Friday, December 13, 2019, at 7:07 PM UTC

Root cause: A common, intermediate carrier in-route for calls to +65 was in a degraded state.

Next steps:
- We're working with the downstream carrier to determine what changes were made that resulted in degradation on the intended call route.

This is the final update for the event.

value.Title: Can't call +65 country code

Messages.MessageText: Updated December 12, 2019: This message has been replaced by MC198011: Clutter for Outlook retirement update. As we previously announced in December 2017, on the Outlook blog, we will be retiring the Clutter feature from Outlook beginning January 31, 2020. To help our users manage their mail and be productive, we are leading with the Focused Inbox experience which provides a similar benefit as Clutter by showing less important and urgent mail in Other. [How does this impact me?] We’ll continue to make Clutter available to Office 365 customers until January 31, 2020. To prepare for Clutter’s eventual retirement, we’ve turned the feature off by default for new users. It’s also deactivated for those with extremely low usage (less than 12 emails per month being moved to the Clutter folder), however they can re-enable Clutter at any time, if desired. [What should I do to prepare for this change?] If your organization is using Clutter today, the process for transitioning to Focused Inbox depends on what version of Outlook you are using. Please review the Additional Information for additional details and guidance for transitioning to Focused Inbox.

value.Title: Updated: Clutter for Outlook is being retired
value.FeatureName: Clutter for Outlook is being retired beginning January 31, 2020

Messages.MessageText:
In February of last year, we announced that starting on October 13, 2020, your organization would need Office 365 ProPlus or Office 2019 apps to connect to Office 365 services. On September 6 of last year, we announced that we would continue supporting Office 2016 connections with Office 365 services through October of 2023. In order for you to better understand if and how your organization is affected by this change, and where you need to take action to migrate users, we’re providing you with two System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) dashboards to help you begin your user migration. 

For larger organizations, we recommend starting this work in the near future in order to meet the October 13, 2020 deadline. 

[How does this affect me?]
Office versions will now be visible in the SCCM Product Lifecycle Dashboard, and a new dashboard will display desktops in your organization that are ready to upgrade to Office 365 ProPlus with high confidence. These two features will be available with SCCM 1902.

These dashboards will help ensure that your users will continue to be supported after October 13, 2020. The Product Lifecycle dashboard will display Office perpetual products, easily distinguishing the desktops that need their Office apps updated from those that do not. The ProPlus Readiness dashboard will identify the desktops that are ready to be upgraded to Office 365 ProPlus.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]
There’s nothing you need to do to prepare for this change. Please click Additional information to learn more about the SCCM Product Lifecycle Dashboards.

value.Title: The Lifecycle Dashboards are now available to help you ensure user access to Office 365

Messages.MessageText: Dynamics 365 sign-in uses a process to determine where to send a user to authenticate after they enter their username on the sign-in screen. This process will be updated with an upgraded user lookup behavior. The new behavior will make intelligent decisions by reading tenant and user level settings based on the username entered on the sign-in page. This will pave the path towards a password-less future by enabling alternative credentials like FIDO (Fast Identity Online) 2.0. [How does this affect me?] After this change takes place, Microsoft will check to see if the username that is entered on the sign-in page exists in their respective domain before deciding where to redirect the user to provide their credentials. Additionally, this behavior will introduce new and improved error messaging on the sign-in pages if the username the user entered does not match an account in the respective domain. [What do I need to do to prepare for this change?] This feature will begin rolling out for managed domains (cloud-only) in May 2019 and for federated domains by the end of 2019. If you or your organization have practices that depend on the old domain level HRD (Home Realm Discovery), it is important that you update the employee authentication documentation, train employees to use their actual username to sign in, and notify your helpdesk of this change. The exact roll out date for federated domains will be dependent on customer feedback. Learn more about this update at https://aka.ms/user-level-HRD/

value.Title: Dynamics 365 - Updates coming to the authentication behavior on Dynamics 365 sign-in pages

Messages.MessageText:
Retention for Teams Hybrid users is a new Office 365 feature. We'll begin rolling this feature out soon.


This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 51587

 

[How does this affect me?]

This feature will be available for Teams Hybrid (on-prem) users who have a shadow mailbox in the cloud. Teams conversations are persistent and retained forever by default. With the introduction of retention policies, admins can configure retention policies (both preservation and deletion) in the Security & Compliance Center for Teams chat and channel messages.

 

This feature is not available in Office 365 subscriptions in GCC.

 

We'll be gradually rolling this out to customers in May 2019.

 

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

In order to use this feature, the administrator would need to set up retention policies for Teams content. Please refer to the Additional Information to learn more.

value.Title: New Feature: Retention for Teams Hybrid users

Messages.MessageText:
We’re seeing significant Teams adoption and positive feedback from the Office 365 deployments that we’ve released thus far. Accordingly, in the second phase of an effort to improve and streamline users initial experience with Teams, we’re making an enhancement so that the Teams desktop client will be added for existing users with Office 365 ProPlus, Microsoft/Office 365 Business, and Microsoft/Office 365 Business Premium apps.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 51452.

[How does this affect me?]

Once available, users will have the Teams desktop client installed, by default, when updating their Office client. This can be managed via the Office Deployment Tool and ExcludeAppelement in a configuration.xml file.

We'll roll this out in the second half of June to Business/Business Premium and Office 365 ProPlus customers on the Monthly update channel. We’ll continue the rollout to desktops on Semi-Annual Channel (Targeted) and Semi-Annual Channel in the coming months.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If you would like to have the Teams desktop client installed, you don’t have to wait. Please see the Additional Information for details on how to manage the install of Teams now. If you do nothing, the Teams desktop client will be installed by default, for users, when you receive this update.

For general information on deploying/managing Teams please see: Microsoft Teams technical documentation.

value.Title: New Feature: Microsoft Teams coming to existing installs of Office 365 ProPlus and Office 365 Business/Business Premium
value.FeatureName: New Feature: Microsoft Teams coming to existing installs of Office 365 ProPlus and Office 365 Business/Business Premium

Messages.MessageText:
The Office mobile apps for Android, will be ending support for Android 4.x (KitKat) and 5.x (Lollipop) on June 30, 2019. Starting on this date, users with devices running on KitKat, Lollipop or older versions of Android will stop receiving app updates. We recommend that your users upgrade to a newer version of Android.

Note: Outlook for Android will continue to support Android KitKat 5.x (Lollipop) until December 31, 2019. After this date, if you are using a device running an older version of Android, you can access your email and calendar by using the mobile web version of Outlook.

[How does this affect me?]

Users who do not upgrade Android in their devices will be able to continue using the Office apps with limited reliability but will not receive any feature or security updates. If they delete the apps they won't be able to download them again until they update their device to a newer Android version.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

We recommend that users upgrade their version of Android or access email and calendar using the mobile web version of Outlook.

value.Title: Office apps for Android - Retiring support for Android 4.x (KitKat) and 5.x (Lollipop)
value.FeatureName: Office apps for Android - Retiring support for Android 4.x (KitKat) and 5.x (Lollipop)

Messages.MessageText:
As previously communicated (MC124104 in Oct 2017, MC126199 in Dec 2017 and MC128929 in Feb 2018), we are moving all of our online services to Transport Layer Security (TLS) 1.2+ to provide best-in-class encryption, and to ensure our service is more secure by default.

Keeping on track with this promise – Office 365 will be retiring TLS 1.0 and 1.1 starting June 1, 2020.

[How does this impact me?]

Starting June 1, 2020, Office 365 will begin retiring TLS 1.0 and 1.1. This means that all connections to Office 365 using the protocols TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 will not work.

[What should I do to prepare for this change?]

Update or replace clients and devices that rely on TLS 1.0 and 1.1 to connect to Office 365, prior to June 1, 2020.

Please click Additional Information to learn more.

value.Title: Office 365 will retire TLS 1.0 and 1.1 starting June 1st, 2020 in Worldwide and GCC Environments
value.FeatureName: Office 365 will retire TLS 1.0 and 1.1 starting June 1st, 2020 in Worldwide and GCC Environments

Messages.MessageText:
In late August, we will start rolling out changes to Office 365 licensing technology to make it more reliable and resilient. These changes will help simplify activation management and streamline the Office activation experience for users.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 53698

[How does this affect me?]

Users will still sign-in to activate Office on their devices, and if single sign-on is enabled, Office will automatically pick up the credentials and activate Office.

As part of your subscription, users can still install and activate Office 365 apps on up to five PCs or Macs, five tablets, and five smartphones. Previously, users who reached this limit were prompted to deactivate an existing install before activating Office on a new device. Going forward, Office will automatically sign the user out of the user’s least recently used device when the user exceeds the limit, eliminating unnecessary friction.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

In late August, we’ll start slowly rolling out these changes to commercial customers on Monthly Channel. No additional action is required on your part.

Please see Additional Information for additional improvements, such as changes to activation reporting and licensing errors.

value.Title: Feature update: Office 365 Client Licensing and Activation Improvements
value.FeatureName: Feature update: Office 365 Client Licensing and Activation Improvements

Messages.MessageText:
Updated November 5, 2019 - In order to provide an optimal experience we are delaying the roll out of this feature until January, 2020. We apologize for any inconvenience.

Save for later on Files is a new Office 365 feature. We'll begin rolling this feature out soon.

This enhancement is related to Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 49095.

[How does this impact me?]

Save for later allows users to keep documents that are interesting to them in an easily accessible list across Office 365. The Save for later command is accessible on files within Personal and Shared Libraries. Documents Saved for later are accessible from the Saved tab in OneDrive on Web.

We'll be gradually rolling this out to customers in January, 2020 (previously early August). The roll out will be completed by the end of March 2020 (previously September).

[What should I do to prepare for this change?]

You don't need to do anything, but you may consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk. Please click Additional information to learn more.

value.Title: New Feature: Save for later on Files

Messages.MessageText:
As Teams has become the core communications client for Office 365, we are announcing that Skype for Business Online will retire on July 31, 2021. 

Note: Neither Skype consumer nor Skype for Business Server will be affected by the retirement of the Skype for Business Online service. Current Skype for Business Online customers will experience no change in the service up to the retirement date.

To align with this schedule, support for the integration of third-party party Audio Conferencing Providers (ACP) into Skype for Business Online has been extended to July 31, 2021, with limited support for remaining active tenants to allow additional time for transition. This is an update in the ACP timeline that was originally announced back in April of 2018.

[How does this affect me?]

You are receiving this message because one or more users in your organization may be using Skype for Business Online. Your organization will no longer be able to use Skype for Business Online once the service is retired on July 31, 2021.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

We actively encourage all customers to plan and execute their upgrade to Teams today.

To enable customers to plan and implement a successful upgrade from Skype for Business Online to Teams, Microsoft offers comprehensive guidance and resources, including a proven success framework, best practices, downloadable assets, free instructor-led training, and FastTrack onboarding assistance for eligible subscriptions.  

Please click Additional Information to learn more.

value.Title: Skype for Business Online is retiring
value.FeatureName: Skype for Business Online is retiring

Messages.MessageText:
Updated August 29, 2019: Providing information on how Admin and Users can control the experience.

To make it easier for your users to take advantage of the rich cloud collaboration capabilities in Office 365, we’ve simplified the first save experience and made it easier for users to save to OneDrive and SharePoint. Once it’s in the cloud, users can easily rename/move files between folders from right within the apps.

This was first announced in MC172548 (January 2019) for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint users on the Monthly Channel. Now, the new save experience will be coming to Semi-Annual Channel users.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID: 45063

[How does this affect me?]

This new experience allows users signed into Office 365 to easily save their Word, Excel & PowerPoint files to a default cloud location. For organizational accounts, this will be OneDrive for Business. Once saved to the cloud, users can easily rename and move the file from within the application to other folders.

This change is already available for all Monthly Channel users and will be a part of the Semi-Annual (Targeted) Release in September. It will then become available to all Office 365 organizations once that Targeted Release version becomes available in January 2020.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If your organization already uses OneDrive and your users already use the OneDrive sync clients, you don’t need to do anything to prepare for this change. You may consider informing your users about this change in user experience, updating any internal help content, and notifying your help desk.

You can control the save dialog experience via Group Policy or a registry key. For details see: What Administrators need to know about the new Save experience in Office

Users can control the new save experience by:

  1. Users can change the default location by right clicking any of the locations shown in the list and selecting “Set as default location”.
  2. Users can set a default local location in File | Options | Save by checking the box to Save to Computer by default and then specifying a Default local file location in the appropriate field.
  3. Users can disable the new save experience by enabling the “Don’t show the Backstage when opening or saving files with keyboard shortcuts” option in File | Options | Save.

If your organization does not use OneDrive, we recommend starting to plan an adoption campaign to take advantage of the cloud, allowing users to securely access their files anywhere and seamlessly work with others, including in real-time. You should deploy the OneDrive sync client, so your users can see all their files in one place and store all their files in the cloud through Windows Explorer. Adoption resources are available at OneDrive Adoption Resources.

Please see Additional Information for more information about this change.

value.Title: Updated - Feature Update: OneDrive will become the default save location in the upcoming Semi-Annual release of Office

Messages.MessageText:
Update August 26, 2019: This update does not apply to customers in GCC High or DOD. We apologize for any confusion.

We will soon be rolling out the ability to use templates to create users in the Microsoft 365 admin center.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 54434.

[How does this affect me?]

Templates provide a new option for efficiently creating multiple users.

Microsoft 365 admin center user templates allow you to save and reuse shared settings for types of users. For example, you can save values for roles, licenses assigned, contact information, and location. When you use the template to create a new user, the saved values in that template will automatically apply to the new user.

We'll be rolling this out to customers in early September. The rollout will be completed worldwide by the end of November.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change.

value.Title: Updated: New feature: Use templates to create users in the Microsoft 365 admin center

Messages.MessageText:
We're making two changes to Microsoft Whiteboard that will roll out over the next 2 months. First, Microsoft Whiteboard for Web is exiting Preview and will be Generally Available (GA). Second, Microsoft Whiteboard will support easy sharing of boards from Surface Hub.

This enhancement is related to Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 54596.

[How does this affect me?]

You are receiving this message because our reporting indicates that Microsoft Whiteboard is available for your tenant. Web and easy share will be enabled by default. If Whiteboard is enabled for your tenant, Web will now be included as part of the setting.

If you would like to disable Whiteboard prior to the GA, you can do so via a tenant-level switch: Enable Microsoft Whiteboard for your organization

We will begin rolling this out at the end of September and expect to be complete by the end of November.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

Review your Whiteboard settings to ensure they are correct for your organization.

If you wish to learn more about the easy share feature for Surface Hub, please read the additional information link.

value.Title: New Feature:  Microsoft Whiteboard Web GA

Messages.MessageText:
Updated October 22, 2019: We have updated the post to reflect the new roll out timeline and provide additional details.

We’re updating how Yammer uses Office profiles. User profiles in Yammer will now use the Office profile rather than the standalone Yammer profile.

This message is associated with Office 365 Roadmap ID 53554.

We'll be gradually rolling this out to customers in early January 2020, and the roll out will be completed worldwide by the end of March.

[How does this affect me?]

Currently, if a Yammer user has a corresponding Office identity, their profile information is synced from Azure Active Directory (AAD) upon their first sign-in on Yammer or if their ADD profile changes. However, Yammer allows users to modify profile information. This can result in situations where information is out of date or scenarios where a user can change their name and photo and then impersonate someone in Yammer.

Going forward:

  • If a Yammer user does not have a corresponding Office identity, they will not be affected by this feature.
  • For Yammer users who do have a corresponding Office identity, we will perform a sync so that Yammer and Office profiles match. Going forward, Yammer users will need to contact their IT administrator, as with other Office 365 apps, in order to change their profile information.

Any Yammer profile fields that cannot be synced with an Office profile, such as a link to a Facebook profile, will be removed during the sync process.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

Ensure your users’ profile information are up to date in Azure Active Directory. There’s no changes to which fields Yammer will sync or how we sync it—Yammer simply will not allow overriding properties synced from AAD.

For users’ profile photos, we will use a new mechanism. To verify your users’ photos will be synced, check one of the following:

  1. The Exchange Online cmdlet Get-UserPhoto returns the correct user photo.
  2. My account page at https://portal.office.com/account/ has their photo.
If you exclusively only store your users’ profile photos in Yammer today, you will need to export the users’ photos in Yammer and re-upload them into Office through Microsoft Graph or Exchange Online APIs.

Please click Additional information to learn more.

value.Title: Updated Feature: Yammer uses your Office profile

Messages.MessageText:
Effective October 1, 2019, changes will be made to PowerApps and Flow licenses, including those available as part of Office 365 subscriptions and the general purpose PowerApps and Flow plans. The changes are as follows:
  • The SQL, Azure and Dynamics 365 connectors listed below will be reclassified from Standard to Premium. A standalone PowerApps or Flow plan license is required to access all Premium connectors.
    • Azure Application Insights
    • Azure Automation
    • Azure Blob Storage
    • Azure Container
    • Azure Cosmos
    • Azure Data Factory
    • Azure Data Lake
    • Azure DevOps
    • Azure Event Grid
    • Azure Event Grid Publish
    • Azure File Storage
    • Azure IoT Central
    • Azure Kusto
    • Azure Log Analytics
    • Azure Log Analytics Data Collector
    • Azure Queues
    • Azure Resource Manager
    • Azure SQL
    • Azure SQL Data Warehouse
    • Azure Table Sorage
    • Dynamics 365
    • Dynamics 365 Customer Insights
    • Dynamics 365 for Finance & Operations
    • Dynamics 365 Sales Insights
    • Dynamics 365 Business Central
    • Dynamics 365 Business Central (on-premises)
    • Dynamics NAV
    • Event Hubs
    • Service Bus
    • SQL Server

  • Two of Flow’s plan-based limits are being removed:

    1. 5-minute maximum flow frequency
    2. 2,000 maximum runs per user, per month

      3. Existing user-based limits on API requests will remain in place for the purposes of service assurance, and there is one new daily API request limit being introduced at this time. Go here to learn more about Flow service limits.

[How does this affect me?] Our records indicate your organization has not used these PowerApps or Flow capabilities recently, so these changes are not expected to have an immediate impact on your users.

After October 1, 2019, a standalone PowerApps or Flow plan license will be required to access all Premium connectors, and it may be necessary to add additional capacity based on your organization’s needs.

If you do plan to use the capabilities after October 1, 2019, you may request an extension to maintain current licensing terms until October 1, 2020 or the expiration of your current Office 365 subscription term, whichever is longer. If you do not request an extension before December 31, 2019, the above changes will go into effect for your tenant at that time.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?] If your organization does not plan to use the PowerApps or Flow capabilities listed above, no action is required.

If you plan to use the capabilities listed above, submit a ticket to request an extension via Microsoft support before December 31, 2019 to maintain current licensing terms until October 1, 2020 or the expiration of your current Office 365 subscription term, whichever is longer. You should assess your current and future usage patterns to determine if additional licensing will be needed.

Please click Additional Information to learn more.

value.Title: Licensing updates for Microsoft Flow & PowerApps in Microsoft 365

Messages.MessageText:
Microsoft Teams - Meet Now is a new Office 365 feature that we will begin rolling out in mid-September.

  • Office 365 subscriptions in GCC will see this change in mid-October.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 54028

[How does this affect me?]

Microsoft Teams users will be able to start an ad hoc private meeting from the Calendar tab in the desktop and browser Teams clients. The feature is not currently available in the mobile client. With this feature, users can initiate a Teams meeting without going through the scheduling process.

The feature is enabled by default.

Once a user clicks on “Meet Now,” Teams will launch a new meeting where the user can add/drag in attendees. Attendees can be inside or outside the organization.

We will begin rolling out this feature in mid-September. GCC customers will see this feature in mid-October. The rollout will be complete worldwide by the end of November.

[What should I do to prepare for this change?]

If you want to disable this feature for a user or a set of users, please change "AllowPrivateMeetNow" in TeamsMeetingPolicy from “True” to "False".

value.Title: New Feature: Microsoft Teams - Meet Now

Messages.MessageText:
We will soon begin rolling out a Secondary Ringer option in Microsoft Teams.

This enhancement is related to Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 51089.

[How does this affect me?]

On your Teams Device settings page, you will be able to choose a secondary ringer from the drop-down of connected devices. This will allow you to hear your incoming Teams call ringer from more than one device, even when a headset is plugged in. 

 

We'll be gradually rolling this out to desktop Windows and Mac customers beginning in mid-September. The roll out will be completed worldwide by mid-October.

[What should I do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change, but you may consider updating your documentation as appropriate. See Control calls using headsets in Teams.

value.Title: New Feature: Teams Secondary Ringer

Messages.MessageText:
We’re updating Exchange Online to accelerate replication of changes to Azure Active Directory.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to customers in early October.
  • The roll out will be completed worldwide by February 2020.

This update does not apply to Office 365 subscriptions in GCC.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 55023.

[How does this affect me?]

As part of continued improvements to the Exchange Online service, we are releasing an improvement to the User object management experience.

Currently, when you create or modify mail user properties via Exchange Admin Center (EAC), Exchange Online PowerShell, or other API, the change replicates to Azure Active Directory (AAD) through a sync mechanism which can take some time.

With this update, admin modifications to mail user properties will be written immediately to AAD, thus reducing replication time. You may see errors referencing AAD when running these management operations when there are transient service issues. You should treat this error like any other PowerShell or management error and simply retry the operation.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change. Be aware that failed commands will generate a new error message.

You can read more about this change here: Exchange Online improvements to accelerate replication of changes to Azure Active Directory

value.Title: Updated Feature: Exchange Online Improvements to Accelerate Replication of Changes to Azure Active Directory

Messages.MessageText:
This is an important communication about the future supported user interface for Dynamics 365 Sales, Dynamics 365 Customer Service, Dynamics 365 Field Service, Dynamics 365 Project Service, and Dynamics 365 Marketing customers. The Microsoft Dynamics 365 legacy web client will be deprecated. Customers must have transitioned to Unified Interface before October 1, 2020. Microsoft will continue to provide support, security updates, and other critical updates to the Dynamics 365 legacy web client until October 1, 2020, but won’t release additional functionality beyond what has already been announced. In addition, the following capabilities will also be removed by October 1, 2020.
  • Process dialogs: Previously announced
  • Task flows: Previously announced
On October 1, 2020, the Dynamics 365 legacy web client, process dialogs, and task flows will no longer be available. In the coming months, for those that have not already made the transition, we will be sending reminders and scheduling updates to transition customers to Unified Interface prior to October 1, 2020. A complete list of all deprecation announcements will be made available at this location.
[What should you do?] If you are currently using the Dynamics 365 legacy web client, we recommend that you take time to review your existing implementation and check compatibility with the Unified Interface. Make the move to the Unified Interface as soon as possible to take advantage of reliability and performance improvements, and the latest functionality. Please also ensure you have a migration plan for process dialogs and task flows. For further information and steps to make a smooth transition, please view our resources and community site:
  • Blog Announcement
  • Learn about Unified Interface
  • Unified Interface Community Group including a Blog and Forum
  • Getting Started Unified Interface Playbook
  • User Experience & Unified Interface Transition Whitepaper
  • Quick Start Guide – add Unified Interface App to existing environment
  • Quick Start Guide – set an environment to Unified Interface as default
  • Introduction to Unified Interface (Video)
  • Unified Interface FAQs
Please note that identification of any issues should follow the standard support process.

value.Title: Dynamics 365 - Announcing a timeline to switch to the Unified Interface

Messages.MessageText:
We will be retiring the Upload Center from Office beginning mid-October 2019. 

[How does this affect me?]

Users will no longer be able to find the files that did not save successfully under the Upload Center when this change is implemented. Instead, we recommend the utilization of the Files Needing Attention experience under File>Open.

 

We'll be gradually rolling this out to the Insiders community in mid-October 2019, and the roll out will be completed by the end of December 2019.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

Instruct users to go to File>Open>Files Needing Attention to Open/Discard files that did not save successfully. If applicable, please update any documentation to reflect the same.  

Please click Additional Information to learn more.

value.Title: Upload Center is being replaced by the in-app Files Needing Attention experience

Messages.MessageText:
If you do not use Whiteboard on Surface Hub you can disregard this notice.

As communicated in MC188851 (August, 2019) easy share for Whiteboard on Surface Hub would be enabled by default when it rolls out. There was a configuration issue with this feature that has now been resolved.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

Verify that your tenant is configured for the desired experience. If you would like easy share enabled there is nothing you need to do. If you would like to disable easy share, please turn off the setting in the admin portal prior to October 10, 2019.

Please click Additional Information to learn more about easy sharing from Surface Hub.

value.Title: Configuration Change for Whiteboard

Messages.MessageText:
Updated September 24, 2019 - added Additional Information

SharePoint Online (SPO) Site Collection Administrators can see all the items in their site that have been shared with any user via the new Office 365 Sharing Reports for SPO feature.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to targeted release customers in late September.
  • We’ll be gradually rolling this out to other customers, including GCC and Department of Defense, in early October.
  • The roll out will be completed worldwide by the end of November.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 27034

[How does this affect me?]

SPO site owners can now generate a CSV that shows how their content is being shared, both inside and outside the organization.

Generate the report which shows all shared content from the "Shared with External Users" section of the Site Usage page. The report outputs a CSV file that contains a row for every unique user, permission, link, and item that has been shared with both internal and external users.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

You don't need to do anything, but you may consider updating your SPO Site Collection Administrators training and notifying your help desk.

value.Title: New Feature: Sharing Reports for SharePoint Online

Messages.MessageText:
As previously announced via blog and MC175274 (March, 2019), Office 2013 clients’ connections to commercial Office 365 services will not be supported after October 13, 2020. After this date, ongoing investments in the Office 365 cloud services – including Exchange Online, SharePoint Online, and OneDrive for Business – will proceed based on post-Office 2013 requirements. We recommend that organizations with Office 2013 clients consider migrating to Office 365 ProPlus.

Support for Office 2016 and Office 2019 connections to Office 365 cloud services will continue until October 2023. Up to date information on current system requirements can be found under on the Office system requirements page, with related timelines available in the Office system requirements matrix.

[How does this affect me?]

Microsoft will not take any active measures to block older Office clients, such as Office 2013 and Office 2010, from connecting to Office 365 services. However, legacy clients attempting to connect to a modern, always up- to- date cloud service may experience performance and reliability issues. Customers will face an increased security risk, and may find themselves out of compliance depending on specific regional or industry requirements. Microsoft Help may not be able to resolve issues that arise due to unsupported service connections.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

In order for you to better understand whether and how your organization is affected by this change, and where you need to migrate users, there are two System Center Configuration Manager dashboards (updated as part of version 1902) that can help:

  • the SCCM Product Lifecycle dashboard allows you to see which versions of Office are running on your desktops, to determine which will need updated Office apps to help ensure a seamless connection to Office 365 services
  • the Office 365 ProPlus Upgrade Readiness report on the Office 365 client management dashboard helps to identify desktops in your organization that are ready to upgrade to Office 365 ProPlus with high confidence.

Use these dashboards to identify users on Office 2010 and Office 2013 clients, deploy Office365 ProPlus or a supported version of Office perpetual to those desktops, and ensure that they will have supported access to Office 365 services after October 13, 2020.

value.Title: Office 2013 Client Connectivity to Office 365 Services

Messages.MessageText:
We’re introducing Use Flow in Office 365 to approve hub site joins in SharePoint Online.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to targeted release customers the first of October.
  • The roll out will be complete worldwide by the end of November 2019.

This update does not apply to Office 365 subscriptions in GCC.

This message is associated with Office 365 Roadmap ID 30552.

[How does this affect me?]

With this feature enabled, hub site owners will have the ability to create approval workflows that designate who can approve a SharePoint site association request.

Administrators can enable or disable hub join approvals for all SharePoint Online site admins in their tenant using the controls in the hub site settings. This feature is off by default.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

You don't need to do anything, but you may consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk.

value.Title: New Feature: Use Flow to approve hub-site joins

Messages.MessageText:
Beginning October 13, 2020, we will retire Basic Authentication for EWS, EAS, IMAP, POP and RPS to access Exchange Online. Note: this change does not impact SMTP AUTH. There are several actions that you and/or your users can take to avoid service disruptions on client applications, and we describe them below. If no action is taken, client applications using Basic Authentication for EWS will be retired on October 13, 2020. Any application using OAuth 2.0 to connect to these protocols, will continue to work without change or interruption. [What do I need to do to prepare for this change?] You have several options on how to prepare for the retirement of Basic Authentication.
  • You can start updating the client applications your users are using to versions that support OAuth 2.0 today. For mobile device access, there are several email apps available that support Modern Authentication, but we recommend switching to the Outlook app for iOS and Android as we believe it provides the best overall experience for your M365 connected users. For desktop/laptop access, we encourage the use of the latest versions of Outlook for Windows and Outlook for Mac. All Outlook versions including, or newer than, Outlook 2013 fully support OAuth 2.0.
  • If you have written your own code using these protocols, you will need to update your code to use OAuth 2.0 instead of Basic Authentication, you can reach out to us on stack overflow with the tag exchange-basicauth if you need some help.
  • If you or your users are using a 3rd party application, which uses these protocols, you will either need to
    • reach out to the 3rd party app developer who supplied this application to update it to support OAuth 2.0 authentication
      • -or-
    • assist your users to switch to an application that’s built using OAuth 2.0.
We are in the process of building reports that will help you identify any impacted users and client applications in your organization. We will make these reports available to you in the next few months and communicate their availability via a follow-up Message center post. Please click Additional Information to learn more about this retirement.

value.Title: Basic Authentication Retirement for legacy protocols in Exchange Online

Messages.MessageText:
We are updating Zero-hour auto purge (ZAP) to move post-delivery identified phish and spam messages to Quarantine to better align the ZAP action to the mail flow action defined in the Anti-spam policy.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to customers in early October.
  • The roll out will be complete worldwide by the end of November.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 55432.

[How does this affect me?]

After this update, ZAP will move post-delivery detected phish or spam mails to Quarantine if the respective phish/spam action in the recipient's Spam policy is set to Redirect, Delete, or Quarantine.

  • If the policy action is set to Move to Junk, then ZAP will continue to move the message to Junk.
  • If the policy action is Add X-header, Modify Subject, or No Action, then ZAP will do nothing.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change.

Learn how to enable Zero-hour auto purge or confirm that it is enabled.

value.Title: Updated Feature: Zero-hour auto purge: move phish and spam to Quarantine

Messages.MessageText:
If your organization is not using macOS then you can disregard this message.

As of the Office 365 for Mac November 2019 update, macOS 10.13.6 or later is required to receive updates to Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook and OneNote. If you continue with an older version of macOS, your Office apps will still work but you will no longer receive any updates including security updates.

To provide you with the best experience, Office for Mac supports Apple’s three most recent versions of macOS. With the upcoming release of macOS 10.15 Catalina, Office 365 for Mac and Office 2019 for Mac will support macOS 10.15, 10.14, and 10.13.

[How does this affect me?]

As part of the upcoming November 2019 update, existing Office 365 for Mac users on macOS 10.12 will not be offered any further updates. Upgrading the operating system to macOS 10.13.6 or later will allow Office updates to proceed. Additionally, new installs of Office 365 for Mac will also require macOS 10.13.6 or later.

Existing Office 365 users on macOS 10.10 or 10.11 will continue receiving Office security updates until October 2020 as they are using the older Office 2016 generation of apps.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

To continue receiving the most up-to-date Office 365 features on Mac, make sure all users are running one of the three most recent versions of macOS.

Learn more about Office 365 and macOS supportability see the Additional Information.

value.Title: Upgrade your macOS to access new Office 365 for Mac updates

Messages.MessageText:
We introduced meeting insights in Outlook on the web to a limited number of customers in the spring.

  • We’ll begin gradually rolling out this feature to Targeted Release customers in late September.
  • The roll out will be complete worldwide by the end of December.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 46196.

[How does this affect me?]

Meeting Insights makes it easy to prepare for meetings. When your customers click on a meeting event in their Outlook on the web calendar, Outlook will suggest relevant content (like emails and files). Content is tailored for each user and users will only see content they are authorized to see. Therefore, meeting participants may not see the same suggested content.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change. Please click the Additional Information link to learn more.

value.Title: Updated feature: Outlook on the web - Meeting Insights

Messages.MessageText:
Microsoft 365 security center and Microsoft 365 compliance center will soon be available to all customers. These centers are currently only available to Microsoft 365 E3 and E5 tenants.

  • We’ll begin gradually rolling out this feature at the end of November 2019.
  • The roll out will be complete worldwide by the end of December.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 55706.

[How does this affect me?]

  • Microsoft 365 security center is the specialized workspace for security admins and security operation admins.
  • Microsoft 365 compliance center is the specialized workspace for compliance, privacy, legal, and risk officers.

Both centers will be available to customers starting in early November. This update will not affect your security and compliance configurations. Access to features is a function of tenant subscription. 

  • For administrators who currently use Office 365 Security & Compliance Center: You can configure and manage your security and compliance settings within this center. The configurations will be maintained in Office 365 Security and Compliance Center as well as Microsoft 365 security center and Microsoft 365 compliance center.  

There are two new workspace URLs for you to share with your teams; both are available in Microsoft 365 admin center:

  • security.microsoft.com
  • compliance.microsoft.com

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change. You may consider informing your administrators about the new URLs that they can visit for managing security and compliance settings once the new experience is rolled out. 

Learn more:

  • Overview of the Microsoft 365 compliance center
  • Overview of the Microsoft 365 security center

value.Title: Microsoft 365 security center and Microsoft 365 compliance center will soon be available

Messages.MessageText:
We will be adding some additional file extensions to the BlockedFileTypes list. The BlockedFileTypes parameter specifies a list of attachment file types (file extensions) that can't be saved locally or viewed from Outlook on the web.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 55100.

This change will roll out in November.

[How does this affect me?]

The newly blocked file types are rarely used, so most organizations will not be affected by the change. If your users are receiving affected attachments, they will report that they are no longer able to download them from Outlook on the Web. This change will roll out beginning the month of October.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If your users are affected, you should first ensure that the application software used to open the required file type is up-to-date (in the case files that are opened by application software) or ensure that your users are familiar with the risks associated with the file types (in the case of files that are interpreted by scripting software).

In order to minimize disruption from this change, we will not add a file extension to a policy's BlockedFileTypes list if that extension is already present in the AllowedFileTypes list. So, if you know that your users require access to any affected file type, you can add those file extensions to the AllowedFileTypes property of your users' OwaMailboxPolicy objects.

You can also remove the file extensions that your organization requires from the affected users' OwaMailboxPolicy configuration after the change rolls out.

For more information, including PowerShell examples of those changes, and a complete list of extensions that will be blocked, please see Additional Information.

value.Title: Updated Feature: Blocked file types in Outlook on the web

Messages.MessageText:
Sharing Reports for OneDrive is a new Office 365 feature.

  • We'll gradually begin rolling this out to targeted release customers in early October.
  • We’ll gradually begin rolling this out to all customers, including GCC and Department of Defense, in late October.
  • The roll out will be completed worldwide by the end of November.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 56194.

[How does this affect me?]

OneDrive owners can now generate a CSV that shows how their content is being shared outside the organization.

OneDrive Owners can generate the report from the OneDrive Settings -> "More Settings" page. The report outputs a CSV file that contains a row for every unique user, permission, link, and item on that site.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

You don't need to do anything, but you may consider updating your OneDrive training and notifying your help desk. To learn more, click the More Information link.

value.Title: New Feature:  Sharing Reports for OneDrive

Messages.MessageText:
Updated December 3, 2019: We have completed the roll out to our Targeted Release customers and to ensure an optimal experience we are extending the completion to remaining customers until February 2020. We apologize for any inconvenience.

We’re updating the SharePoint start page experience

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to selected Targeted Release customers in early October 2019.
  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to all customers on November 1, 2019.
  • The roll out will be completed by the end of February 2020 (previously November 2019).

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 54821.

[How does this affect me?]

The SharePoint start page, previously known as SharePoint home, has a new look and feel. This is the personalized SharePoint page that users see when clicking on SharePoint in Office.com or the Office 365 app launcher.

We are also adding new experiences to the start page to help users discover and get back to their content easily.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]
