Messages.MessageText:
Office 365 ProPlus delivers cloud-connected and always up-to-date versions of the Office desktop apps. To ensure that customers get the best value and experience from Office 365 ProPlus, we are sending this reminder as to the impact of upcoming changes to Windows support on Office 365 ProPlus.

[How does this affect me?]

As communicated in MC192504 (October 2019), we noted Windows 7 will go out of support after January 14, 2020. At this time, Windows Server 2008 will also go out of support. We understand Office 365 ProPlus customers may need more time in their migration to a supported operating system. Through January 2023, Microsoft will provide security updates for Office 365 ProPlus on Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008. But, during that time, as long as customers are still running one of these unsupported operating systems, Office 365 ProPlus won’t receive any new feature updates.

For Windows Server 2012/R2, we previously announced and stated in a support article, that Office 365 ProPlus will no longer be supported on Windows Server 2012 and 2012 R2. While Microsoft will not take any measures to block users with this configuration from connecting to Office 365 services, Office 365 ProPlus on Windows Server 2012/R2 will not be a supported configuration. While Microsoft does not anticipate any change to Office 365 ProPlus compatibility with Windows Server 2012/R2, customers may experience changes to performance or reliability issues. Microsoft Support will continue to accept calls from customers, however we may not be able to resolve issues that arise if those issues are determined to be unique to this configuration.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

For customers on Windows 7, we recommend that organizations migrate to Windows 10 or a supported operating system before the end of support date on January 14, 2020 in order to continue receiving new feature updates to Office 365 ProPlus. For more information, please refer to this article.

For customers on Windows Server 2008/R2 and Windows Server 2012/R2, we recommend migrating your applications to Azure. For those customers who need to stay on-premises, we recommend moving to Windows Server 2019.

Related Message Center Posts:

  • MC192504 (October 2019) - Retiring support for Windows 7 and impact on Office 365 ProPlus
  • MC190854 (September 2019) - Office 2013 Client Connectivity to Office 365 Services

value.Title: Windows Server 2008/R2 and Windows Server 2012/R2 end of Support and Office 365 ProPlus

Messages.MessageText:
We’re updating SharePoint list appearance and functionality as part of the modern SharePoint experience.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out in late November 2019.
  • The rollout will be completed in early December 2019.

This message is associated with Office 365 Roadmap IDs 46102 and 57306.

[How does this affect me?]

In 2016, we introduced a modern experience for SharePoint focused on extensibility, accessibility, and responsive design. However, classic mode remains supported and available.

We are introducing two new modern features for SharePoint lists.

First, users will be able to enable and disable column totals in the modern list user experience. Currently, that capability is limited to the classic mode.

Second, users will be able to create a document view for list data that features column formatting and/or alternating colors by row. This example shows both, with the edit panel highlighted.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change, but you might want to update your user training.

Learn more:

  • Build your modern intranet on SharePoint in Office 365
  • Content collaboration throughout Microsoft 365 – Microsoft Ignite 2019 announcements
  • Maximize use of modern lists and libraries
  • SharePoint roadmap pitstop: January 2019

value.Title: Updated Feature: SharePoint list Modern Settings

Messages.MessageText:
We are rolling out updates to Office 365 Message Encryption (OME) that enhance the authenticity of OME email.

  • We will roll out these features in early January 2020.
  • The rollout will be complete the first of February.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59001.

[How does this affect me?]

There are four changes in this update.

1. Updated email layout for encrypted messages

The recipient alert advising users about an encrypted message will not feature the Microsoft logo.

2. OME email will use the customer domain

OME email will use the organization domain instead of instead of Microsoft’s domain address ‘messaging.onmicrosoft.com’. This change improves the authenticity of the one-time passcode and OME portal emails.

3. Reduced odds that OME email will be identified as spam

We are improving how we validate and identify that OME email originates from your domain in Office 365. This reduces the likelihood that mail servers that receive OME email will mark that email as spam. We’ve added DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM)and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance (DMARC) validation for outgoing encrypted mail. We’ve also set up special DKIM headers for one-time passcode email to prevent them from being marked as junk in Office 365.

4. Capture non-delivery receipt (NDR) email

Create a bounces@ mailbox to capture NDR email in the OME portal.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

1. Updated email layout for encrypted messages

We encourage you to create your own branding in preparation for this update. Learn how to add your organization’s brand to encrypted messages.

2. OME email will use the customer domain

Admins who have rules that refer to ‘messaging.onmicrosoft.com’ will need to update the rule. Any users who have mailbox rules that refer to the Microsoft domain will also need to update their rules. Learn how to define mail flow rules to encrypt email messages in Office 365.

3. Reduced odds that OME email will be identified as spam

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change. Learn more:

  • Use DKIM to validate outbound email sent from your custom domain in Office 365.
  • Use DMARC to validate email in Office 365.

4. Capture non-delivery receipt (NDR) email

If you want to capture NDR email, create a bounces@<your organization domain> mailbox. See Create user mailboxes in Exchange Online.

value.Title: New Feature:  Office 365 Message Encryption (OME) updates to enhance email authenticity

Messages.MessageText:
Updated December 6, 2019: We have updated the roll-out timeline.

We're expanding the in-product help that appears at the top-right of your SharePoint team sites.

  • We'll begin gradually rolling this out to targeted release customers mid-January (previously December).
  • The rollout will be completed by the end of February 2020 (previously January).

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 46832.

[How does this affect me?]

SharePoint will help your users build new sites by providing contextual help. To see the tips, click on the megaphone in the Office 365 suite header above the team site.

Currently there are four tips your users might see: upload files, add members, post news, and add additional Office 365 Group apps.

These tips help your users customize and improve their team sites. Tips are useful for anyone learning more about SharePoint or setting up a new team site for the first time.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change.

value.Title: Updated feature: SharePoint team sites ‘Next steps’ panel

Messages.MessageText:
We are enhancing phishing protection in Microsoft Forms by restricting repeated offenders who are trying to phish. This is an update to MC185734 (July 2019).

  • We will roll out this feature in early December 2019.
  • The rollout will be complete by the end of December.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59216.

[How does this affect me?]

The Microsoft Forms automated machine review will block users who have two or more confirmed phishing forms from distributing forms and collecting responses.

We will send global and security admins daily notifications of any form created within your tenant that has been blocked for potential phishing; you can unblock restricted users via the Restricted User Portal.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change, but you may wish to update your training and documentation as appropriate.

Learn how to review and unblock forms or users detected and blocked for potential phishing.

value.Title: Updated Feature: Handling repeated phishers in forms

Messages.MessageText:
We are enabling meeting chat notifications for Teams.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out in early December 2019.
  • The rollout will be completed by mid-December.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 54637.

[How does this affect me?]

By default, meeting chats will be muted until a user either sends a message in the chat or joins the online meeting.

  • Users who have joined a meeting, whether or not they have sent a message in the meeting chat, will receive notifications of chat messages for that meeting unless they have modified their settings.
  • Users who send a message in a meeting chat will receive notifications for chat messages for that meeting unless they have modified their settings.

Users can change the default setting:

  • In the web browser or desktop client, users should tap their profile picture at the top right of the app, select Settings > Notifications.
  • In the mobile client, users should access the "Hamburger" menu and choose Settings > Notifications.
  • Then navigate to the meetings section and open the menu for Meeting chat notifications.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change, but you may consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk.

value.Title: New Feature:  Meeting chat notifications

Messages.MessageText:
SharePoint classic blogs and Delve blogs are being retired. Existing SharePoint classic blogs will continue to work as expected, including the ability to create new posts, but you will not be able to create new blog sites after a period of time.

Delve blogs will no longer be available for creation, and existing blogs will eventually be removed, after an extended period of read only access.

[How does this affect me?]

If you use SharePoint classic blogs, be aware that:

  • Beginning January 18th, 2020, the classic blog site template name will change to "Blogs (retired)”.
  • Beginning July 17th, 2020, the ability to create new classic blog sites through the user interface will be turned off. 

If you use Delve blogs, be aware that:

  • Beginning January 18th, 2020, tenants will not have the ability to create new Delve blogs.
  • Beginning February 18th, 2020 the ability to create new, or edit existing posts, in existing Delve blogs will be disabled.
  • Beginning July 17th, 2020, existing Delve blogs will be deleted and removed from Delve profiles.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

Plan to use alternative methods of blogging. We recommend creating Communication sites using News, Yammer, and Stream as a modern way of engaging with your audience.

See this article on how to setup a great blogging site : Creating a blog with communications sites and news posts

If you’d like to transition your existing blog content to a modern communication site, that is possible using the community supported PnP Page transformation tool, available here: Modernize Delve blogs and classic blogs

value.Title: Retirement of SharePoint classic and Delve blogs

Messages.MessageText:
Soon users who are already part of a private meeting chat will be able to add users to the chat.

We'll be rolling this out in mid-December.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59386.

[How does this affect me?]

Currently, users cannot easily add participants to a private meeting chat thread.

This feature adds an option, Add participants, to the meeting chat header. Users who are already part of the chat thread will be able to add more users using this feature. The process works like it does in group chat. 

Users added to via chat will be able to join the meeting. After selecting the Join button in the meeting chat header, these users will be able to send/view messages as well as view recordings and other meeting artifacts.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is no action you need to take to prepare for this change, but you might consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk.

value.Title: New Feature: Add participants to Teams Meeting chat

Messages.MessageText:
We are introducing File Upload for Microsoft Forms.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out in early December 2019.
  • The rollout will be completed by the end of December 2019.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59344.

[How does this affect me?]

This new feature allows form designers to choose a new question type, File Upload, which enables respondents to attach files as part of their response.

  • Files can be accessed in either SharePoint or OneDrive for Business, depending on the form type. Group forms are stored in SharePoint, while personal forms are stored in OneDrive for Business.
  • Form creators can limit the number and size of files as well as specify file types. 

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is no action you need to take to prepare for this change, but you might consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk. Please click the Additional information link to see an animation of the feature.

value.Title: New Feature: Introducing File Upload for Forms

Messages.MessageText:
The self-serve Microsoft Teams Commercial Cloud Trial offer will soon be replaced with the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience. This improved trial experience allows existing Azure Active Directory (AAD) users in your organization who are not licensed for Microsoft Teams to initiate a trial of the product.

We'll be gradually rolling this out to our customers starting January 2020.

[How does this affect me?]

We have updated the end user sign-up process for the Teams Exploratory experience and included an Exchange mailbox component.

Additionally, to provide visibility, tenant admins will receive an email notification for the initial user completing sign up for the Teams Exploratory experience.

This new experience is enabled by default and if you do not want users to self-sign up, or you’d like to remove access to the Teams Exploratory experience, you can turn off that capability in your organization’s settings: Manage the Microsoft Teams Exploratory license. If you have previously disabled this capability we will honor your settings and no changes will be made.

If you have previously signed up for the Teams Commercial Cloud Trial there is no action as your tenant will be migrated to the new Teams Exploratory experience prior to the expiration of your current trial experience.

Use of the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience is provided under the Microsoft Online Subscription Agreement (MOSA). By allowing your users to use the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience, you agree to the terms of the MOSA as the applicable terms governing use of the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience.

Users will be presented with an End User Notice as a part of the sign-up flow letting them know that the MOSA terms entered into between the Customer (You) and Microsoft apply to their use of the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience.

The Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience is offered as a Limited Offer for a specified Term, as defined in the MOSA. Upon expiration of the Term, rights to access or use the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience will end, or may otherwise be modified, as specified in the MOSA. To allow users to continue to enjoy Microsoft Teams after the expiration of the trial period Term, you must purchase a subscription for Microsoft Teams.

If you elect not to purchase a subscription to Microsoft Teams before expiration of the Teams Exploratory experience Term, a) Microsoft has no obligation to return Customer Data to you; b) Microsoft will retain such Customer Data for at least 90 days after the expiration of the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience, and Microsoft will make commercially reasonable efforts to work with you to export any such Customer Data if requested, and c) Microsoft may contact users at your organization’s domain email address regarding the Microsoft Teams Exploratory experience.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

Review the documentation and ensure your settings are appropriate for the experience that you would prefer.

Please click the Additional information link to learn about managing this experience.

value.Title: Updated Feature: Microsoft Teams Commercial Cloud Trial updates

Messages.MessageText: We have postponed the release of Service Update 109 for your Microsoft Dynamics 365 (online) organization in the OCE region. [How does this affect me?] We are combining the updates for Service Update 109 into Service Update 111. Please check your Message Center for release information and timing for Service Update 111. [What action do I need to take?] Communicate as appropriate with your Dynamics 365 Admin and users. Please contact support if you experience any issues.

value.Title: Dynamics 365 - Postponed - Service Update 109 for OCE

Messages.MessageText:
We have a minor service update planned for your Microsoft Dynamics 365 (online) organization in the OCE region.
 
Maintenance window start: 11 January 2020, 11:00 UTC
Maintenance window end: 11 January 2020, 21:00 UTC
 
[How does this affect me?]
As part of this service update, the following feature areas may be affected:
The version number for your Microsoft Dynamics 365 (online) organization will update to version 9.1.0.11701 or higher after the background database operations complete. 
 
Although there is no expected degradation to service performance or availability, this service update is planned outside of normal business hours to help minimize any potential impact to your organization. During this maintenance window users may see short, intermittent impact such as transient SQL errors or a redirect to the login screen. If impact occurs outside of this maintenance window, please contact Microsoft Support.

For organizations with users around the globe, we recognize that "outside of normal business hours" might affect you differently. We apologize for the impact this may have on your users. We are working hard to improve Microsoft Dynamics 365 (online) and minimize the impact of these maintenance windows.
 
[What action do I need to take?]
Communicate as appropriate with your Dynamics 365 Admin and users. Please contact support if you experience any issues.

Messages.MessageText:
Our goal with Dynamics 365 and the Microsoft Power Platform is to help your organization drive more impactful business outcomes and take proactive actions that will uniquely position and differentiate your business in the fast-evolving market.

As announced at Microsoft Ignite 2019, Microsoft Flow is being renamed to Microsoft Power Automate to better align with the Microsoft Power Platform. We've also released additional updates to the Microsoft Power Platform that unlock new possibilities. To read about all of the exciting changes that have been made to the Microsoft Power Platform please see our blog.

value.Title: Microsoft Flow is becoming Power Automate!

Messages.MessageText:
With this update, your users will be able to install Outlook on the web as a progressive web app in Chromium-based browsers.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out in mid-December.
  • The rollout will be complete by the end of January 2020.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59250.

[How does this affect me?]

PWAs are websites that that provide native app-like features on supporting platforms and browser engines. When Outlook is installed as a PWA, users can launch it from the Start menu, pin it to the Taskbar, or run it in a standalone browser window that removes standard browser interface elements. Microsoft will continue to update Outlook on the web with additional app-like capabilities.

Each Chromium-based browser has a unique set of steps that users need to follow to enable PWAs.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is no action you need to take to prepare for this change, but you might consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk.

Learn how to use the web version of Outlook like a desktop app.

value.Title: New Feature:  Outlook on the web as a progressive web app

Messages.MessageText:
Office 365 Advanced Threat Protection (ATP) campaign views is a new Office 365 feature. We'll begin rolling this feature out as a public preview starting today.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 53661

[How does this affect me?]

The preview feature will be available for Office365 ATP P2 (and E5) customers. In Security and Compliance Portal, existing Threat Intelligence -> Explore views for Phish and All email will include a Top Campaigns tab. The feature is new addition and a much better way to look at the big picture of attacks and distil their important aspects (timeline, targets, filtering and configurations verdicts, who clicked on what phish link and when).

Go to Explorer, Phish View:

Click on any of the campaigns:

Note: The feature will not impact any of the existing UX flows or functionality in Threat Intelligence, and it does not have any configuration settings associated with it.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

Review the blog post and Additional Information to learn more.

value.Title: New Feature: Advanced Threat Protection campaign views public preview

Messages.MessageText:
As announced at Microsoft Ignite 2019, Microsoft Flow is being renamed to Microsoft Power Automate to better align with the Microsoft Power Platform.

[How does this affect me?]

You will start to see Microsoft Flow be replaced by Microsoft Power Automate throughout the service. These changes will start to become visible in Microsoft documentation, Admin center, etc. in the near future.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is no specific action associated with this change. You may want to update your training and documentation as appropriate.

Please see the Additional Information to learn about this change and other changes made to the Microsoft Power Platform.

value.Title: Microsoft Flow is becoming Microsoft Power Automate

Messages.MessageText:
For the last year, we've been providing a set of suggested Q&As to help you set up Microsoft Search. We learned from customer feedback that customers prefer to create their own Q&As, so we are removing the suggested set on January 10, 2020 to clean up the list. The ability to create, edit, and publish your own Q&As will remain unchanged.

[How does this affect me?]

As an admin, you can easily save or publish these suggested Q&As by following the steps below:

To export the entire set of Q&As as a CSV file for safekeeping:

  1. Visit the Microsoft Search admin center
  2. Select Q&A
  3. Select Export

To edit and publish suggested Q&As:

  1. Visit the Microsoft Search admin center
  2. Select Q&A
  3. Select Suggested (the ones that have a blank “Answer Description” field need to be edited)
  4. Look for a question your users might ask. Then select Edit and add an applicable answer.
  5. Publish (or Save to draft)
  6. Repeat steps 4–5 for all suggested Q&As you want to publish or save 

[How do I prepare for this change?]

Review the suggested Q&A's and if you would like to keep them, follow the steps above by January 10, 2020. If you do not wish to use the suggested Q&A's there is nothing you need to do.

Looking for more information on how to customize Microsoft Search? See the Microsoft Search documentation for helpful hints on making content searchable, customizing search result layouts, indexing third-party data, and much more.

value.Title: Updated Feature: Microsoft Search Change to suggested Q&As

Messages.MessageText:
In February 2019 we communicated MC173616 Clutter for Outlook is being retired beginning January 31, 2020. We received feedback from our customers and in response, we are going to postpone the retirement of Clutter at this time.

Focused Inbox is where we will be focusing our development efforts moving forward and we would encourage you to transition for the best experience. Customers can continue to use Clutter, but we will not be investing in it further.

We appreciate your feedback and ask that you continue to provide as we work to improve the Microsoft 365 services.

value.Title: Clutter for Outlook retirement update

Messages.MessageText:
As communicated in MC193076 we added High confidence phishing email to the spam filter policy. Starting January 6, 2020 we will enable the policy.

[How does this affect me?]

The change announced in MC193076 added High confidence phishing email to the spam filter policy. By default, the action is set to Quarantine message for all new and existing policies. Just as with the existing Phishing email Quarantine behavior, only admins will be able to access these messages within Quarantine. Administrators can manage quarantined email messages in the Security & Compliance Center and the Exchange Admin Center.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If you have already verified the appropriate action for High confidence phishing email, your settings will be honored and there is no action at this time. If you want to take a different action other than Quarantine message for High confidence phishing email then you should change the selection before January 6, 2020.

Please click the Additional information link to learn more.

value.Title: Reminder: Introducing 'High confidence phishing email' to the spam filter policy

Messages.MessageText:
The Microsoft Teams desktop app will be added to existing installations of Office 365 ProPlus on the Semi-Annual Channel on Jan 14, 2020, as announced in May (MC180551).

  • Beginning January 14, 2020, the Teams client will be added to existing installations for customers on the Semi-Annual Channel.
  • Teams will then auto-update on a regular cadence.

This message is associated with Office 365 Roadmap IDs 51452 and 56828.

[How does this affect me?]

Starting in July 2019, we began integrating Teams into Office 365 ProPlus to make it easier for organizations to adopt. That integration is now coming to our Semi-Annual Channel customers.

As part of the normal update process, the desktop Teams client will be installed by default on devices running Windows. There is no change to existing installations on Mac devices. This change does not affect users who already have Teams installed on their machines.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If you do nothing, the Teams desktop client will be installed by default for your users when your tenant receives the semi-annual channel update.

If you don't want Teams to be added to existing installations of Office 365 ProPlus when you update to a newer version, disable the auto-update via a Group Policy or the Office Deployment Tool.

Alternatively, you can allow Teams to install and use a Group Policy to prevent Teams from automatically starting when users sign in to their device. To change this behavior, you must act before Teams is deployed.

Learn more:

  • Learn more about deploying Teams with Office 365 ProPlus
  • See our guide to help you plan your rollout.

value.Title: Update: Microsoft Teams coming to existing installs for Semi-Annual Channel customers

Messages.MessageText:
We’re updating the user account management experience, My Account, in Office.com and Office web applications.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to customers in late-January 2020. 
  • The roll out is expected to be completed by the end of March 2020.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 57078.

[How does this affect me?]

When end users select the “View account” link in the upper right corner of the Office portal header, they will be redirected to a new account management experience.

This new account management site has the same functionality as the current site but with a different look-and-feel. The new site is also combined with the Azure Active Directory account experience. It provides a user access to their security info, password reset, devices, and more.

Tenant admins who use the Azure Active Directory portal will also see the new account page.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is no action you need to take to prepare for this change, but you might consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk. Please click the Additional information link to learn more.

value.Title: Updated Feature: New account management experience

Messages.MessageText:
The Microsoft Fluid Framework preview experience has started rolling out to targeted release customers as announced in MC194816 (November 2019).

  • This preview experience is accessible in English (US) environments only.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 56781.

[How does this affect me?]

The Fluid Preview experience announced at Ignite 2019 is beginning to roll out to targeted release tenants. It will progress to all tenants in the first quarter of 2020. Get started at fluidpreview.com

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is nothing you need to do to prepare for this change.

  • Learn how to manage tenant access to the preview.
  • Learn how to use the preview.

value.Title: Updated Feature: Fluid Framework Preview

Messages.MessageText:
Teams-Outlook Email Integrations is a set of three new features designed to help you share information between Microsoft Teams and Outlook:

  • Share email to Teams
  • Share a copy of an email and any attachments from Outlook to a channel or chat in Teams.
  • Share conversation via email
  • Share a copy of a Teams channel or chat conversation via email directly from the Teams client.
  • Reply to Teams missed activity emails
  • Ability to respond to Teams missed activity emails directly within Outlook clients, as well as see the latest missed messages.

Rolling into general availability starting in mid-January and complete roll out by early February.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 57389

[How does this affect your organization]

These integrations enable users to seamlessly get information and move conversations to where they belong. Whether a customer request begins through email and needs to move to a project team in Teams, or a big announcement in a channel needs to be shared with a broader audience via email, you now have the tools to easily make it happen.

Teams missed activity emails now show the latest missed messages and provide the ability to respond directly from within Outlook, letting you respond to conversations that need your attention faster, even when focusing on your inbox.

More Details

  • Share to Teams is an Outlook add-in.
  • Share to Teams does not allow sharing IRM/DRM protected emails.
  • All content is fully e-discoverable and GDPR compliant.
  • Reply to missed activity emails uses Outlook Actionable Messages.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

You don't need to do anything, but you may consider updating your user training and notifying your helpdesk. Please click Additional information to learn more.

value.Title: New Feature: Teams-Outlook Email Integrations

Messages.MessageText:
We're introducing a new way to see disposed records in Records management.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out in early January 2020.
  • The roll out will be completed by the end of February 2020.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59217.

[How does this affect me?]

If you are using retention labels to declare items as records, you will be able to see the list of record labels under the "Disposition" tab of Records management solution within the Microsoft 365 Compliance Center.

Under these labels, you will see the complete list of disposed items corresponding to that label, both those disposed of automatically as well as through a disposition review.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

There is no action you need to take to prepare for this change, but you might consider updating your training for users of the Compliance Center and sharing with your Records Management team.

value.Title: New Feature: Retention labels, proof of disposal for records

Messages.MessageText:
We are modifying how your users access Office.com apps.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to targeted release customers in mid-January 2020.
  • The rollout will be complete by early February 2020. 

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59667.

[How does this affect me?]

Currently, your users can manage pinned applications by accessing the Office 365 app launcher. The most recently accessed applications will appear on the Office.com home page. The apps shown in the Office 365 app launcher and on the Office.com home page may currently not be the same.

With this change, users will see the same set of applications on Office.com that they see in the Office 365 app launcher. By default, both will display all launched apps.

In addition, admins can now pin up to three apps to the top of the Office 365 app launcher. These apps will also appear on Office.com by default.

Notes for your end users:

  • Initially, users may find that their list of launched apps on Office.com is temporarily out-of-sync with the list in the Office 365 app launcher due a sync lag.
  • Users can no longer explicitly pin an app to the Office 365 app launcher.
  • Users can unpin any app from Office 365 app launcher, including those pinned by admins. App tiles in the app launcher will have an unpin option from the context menu. Office.com will introduce an "x" upon hover for each app tile.
  • Users will need to refresh the page after making a change in the Office 365 app launcher or list of launched apps on Office.com in order for the two views to appear in sync.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If you want to pin a third party or line of business application to the Office 365 app launcher, first configure it as an Enterprise Application in Azure Active Directory (AAD).

To pin an Enterprise Application:

  • Go to the AAD portal
  • Go to Enterprise applications - User settings
  • Scroll to Office 365 settings and add the default applications (up to three)

value.Title: New Feature: New features coming to the Office 365 app launcher and Office.com

Messages.MessageText:
We are updating how FindTime stores polling data.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to targeted release customers in mid-December 2019.
  • The rollout will be completed by the end of March 2020.

This message is associated with Microsoft Office 365 Roadmap ID 58210.

[How does this affect me?]

FindTime is an Outlook add-in that helps your users quickly find time to meet with others by simplifying group scheduling via a poll. Customers have asked that FindTime store application data at the organization’s location. To address this, the new FindTime service will now store collected data in the meeting organizer’s Exchange mailbox.

The new FindTime service will be supported in Outlook on the web, Outlook for Windows 2016 version 2016.0.7828.100 and above, and Outlook for Mac 2016. Find out what version of Outlook you have.

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If you have not enabled FindTime for your organization, this update does not apply to you.

If you have enabled FindTime for your organization:

  • For your users who have a supported version of Outlook, their FindTime polling data will be stored in their Exchange mailbox.
  • For your users who have a non-supported version of Outlook, their FindTime polling data will be stored in a North America server.

Learn more:

  • Find out what version of Outlook you have
  • How do I install FindTime for everyone in my organization?
  • How does FindTime work?
  • How FindTime treats personal information
  • Outlook is committed to FindTime and to making group scheduling easier

value.Title: Updated Feature:  FindTime, updating back-end service

Messages.MessageText:
We are introducing a new experience for Outlook on the web in mobile browsers.

  • We'll be gradually rolling this out to targeted release customers in mid-December.
  • The roll out will be completed by the end of January 2020.

This message is associated with Microsoft 365 Roadmap ID 59334.

[How does this affect me?]

When this experience is available to them, users who have opted into the new Outlook on the web on a desktop browser (see MC197736, December 2019) will experience the new Outlook on the web in a mobile browser by default when they sign into their accounts.

Users can opt-in or opt-out of the new mobile browser experience by going to the toolbar and tapping the icon in the upper left corner:

Then slide the toggle on or off:

[What do I need to do to prepare for this change?]

If you have blocked the opt-in toggle for the new Outlook on the web, your users will not see the toggle in a mobile browser. You can change this policy using PowerShell.

If you have not blocked the opt-in toggle for the new Outlook on the web:

  • If you don't want your users to see the opt-in toggle for the new Outlook in a mobile browser, follow these instructions to block the toggle.
  • If you want your users to see the opt-in toggle in a mobile browser, there is nothing you need to do.

If you are allowing access to the opt-in toggle, you might consider updating your user training and notifying your help desk.

Please click the Additional information link to learn more.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Can't connect

User Impact: Users may be unable to access multiple Office 365 services.

More info: Users may be unable to access Skype for Business, Microsoft Teams, SharePoint Online and Exchange Online. 

Current status: We're investigating a potential issue where some users may be unable to access multiple services. We're reviewing systems data to determine the source of the issue. 

Scope of impact: Impact is specific to a subset of users in Europe and the United Kingdom, who are served through the affected infrastructure. 

Next update by: Monday, November 18, 2019, at 10:30 AM UTC

Title: Can't connect

User Impact: Users may be unable to access multiple Office 365 services.

More info: Users may see latency when trying to connect to the Skype for Business, Microsoft Teams, SharePoint Online and Exchange Online services. 

Current status: We've identified a section of networking infrastructure is in an unhealthy state and are investigating whether this is the cause of the issue. Our automated tooling is routing user request traffic to alternate, healthy networking infrastructure to mitigate impact. Users may see some latency connecting to the service while we work on fully restoring service. 

Scope of impact: Impact is specific to a subset of users in Europe and the United Kingdom, who are served through the affected infrastructure. 

Next update by: Monday, November 18, 2019, at 12:00 PM UTC

Title: Can't connect

User Impact: Users may have been unable to access multiple Office 365 services.

Final status: We isolated the unhealthy section of networking infrastructure, which ensured user request traffic was routed to alternate, healthy networking infrastructure. We monitored the service and confirmed that impact was remediated. In parallel to this networking issue, a 3rd party Internet Service Provider (ISP) in the United Kingdom was experiencing issues, which may have also caused impact to connectivity to some of the Office 365 service. While we fixed the networking issue at 10:40 AM UTC, users routing traffic via the 3rd party ISP may have continued to see some intermittent impact until the ISP resolved their issue at approximately 12:30 PM UTC on Monday, November 18, 2019.

Scope of impact: Impact was specific to a subset of users in Europe and the United Kingdom, who were served through the affected infrastructure. 

Start time: Monday, November 18, 2019, at 8:32 AM UTC 

End time: Monday, November 18, 2019, at 10:40 AM UTC 

Root cause: A section of networking infrastructure fell into an unhealthy state. In parallel to this networking issue, a 3rd party  Internet Service Provider (ISP) in the United Kingdom was experiencing issues, which may have also caused impact to connectivity to some of the Office 365 service.

Next steps:
We'll replace the networking hardware that caused the section of networking infrastructure to become unhealthy to prevent this from happening in the future. 

This is the final update for the event.

Title: Can't access Microsoft 365

User Impact: Users may have been unable to access Microsoft 365 services.

More info: We've identified that users may have intermittently experienced this problem with the Microsoft 365 admin center, Exchange Online, SharePoint Online, Microsoft Teams, Microsoft Intune, Skype for Business, and Yammer.

While Microsoft Intune was also affected by this issue, Intune admins were able to work around the impact by accessing portal.azure.com. This was not a confirmed method of alternative access for other affected Microsoft 365 services.

Final status: We've confirmed that reverting the networking update was successful in restoring service functionality; though, we anticipate that some users may still see residual impact as the service progresses to full recovery.

Scope of impact: Any users may have been intermittently affected by this problem.

End time: Wednesday, November 20, 2019, at 3:40 AM UTC

We'll publish a post-incident report within five business days.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Missing Microsoft 365 (M365) groups reports for December 11, 2019

User Impact: Admins are unable to view the M365 groups report for December 11, 2019.

More info: Admins may have noticed that reports for December 12, 2019 and December 13, 2019 were impacted by this issue. These reports have been generated and should be visible now.

Current status: We've determined that the upstream data source responsible for generating the M365 groups reports hadn't been properly updated, causing a backlog of reports within our systems and subsequently failing to generate for reports from December 11, 2019, to December 13, 2019. We've updated the data source to resolve this issue for future reports and we've confirmed that reports for December 12, 2019 and December 13, 2019 have successfully processed. Messages.MessageText:
Title: Can't sync policies

User Impact: Admins are unable to sync policies to their tenants. 

Current status: We've identified a configuration issue that is preventing policies set by administrators from syncing across their managed environments. We're developing a fix to address the configuration problem and restore policy syncing functionality.

Scope of impact: This issue may affect any admins attempting to update and sync policies to their tenant.

Start time: Tuesday, November 26, 2019, at 11:00 AM UTC

Root cause: A configuration issue is preventing policies set by administrators from syncing.

Next update by: Friday, November 29, 2019, at 11:00 AM UTC

Title: Can't sync policies

User Impact: Admins are unable to sync policies to their tenants.

Current status: We’ve started deploying the fix to address the configuration issue and the deployment is 80% complete. Once the deployment completes, we’ll turn-on the configuration to enable policy sync and validate resolution. 

Scope of impact: This issue may affect any admins attempting to update and sync policies to their tenant. 

Start time: Tuesday, November 26, 2019, at 11:00 AM UTC

Root cause: A configuration issue is preventing policies set by administrators from syncing. 

Next update by: Friday, November 29, 2019, at 2:30 PM UTC

Title: Can't sync policies

User Impact: Admins are unable to sync policies to their tenants.

Current status: The deployment of the fix is progressing as expected. We enabled the configuration on a limited subset of the infrastructure where the fix was deployed and confirmed that the fix is working. Once the deployment completes, we’ll turn-on the configuration for the rest of the affected infrastructure to enable policy sync and validate resolution. 

Scope of impact: This issue may affect any admins attempting to update and sync policies to their tenant. 

Start time: Tuesday, November 26, 2019, at 11:00 AM UTC

Estimated time to resolve: We expect this issue to be resolved for all users by 11:30 PM UTC on 29th November, 2019. 

Root cause: A configuration issue is preventing policies set by administrators from syncing. 

Next update by: Friday, November 29, 2019, at 10:30 PM UTC

Title: Can't sync policies

User Impact: Admins are unable to sync policies to their tenants.

Current status: We’ve determined that the fix to remediate the policy sync issue is 96 percent deployed and will reach full saturation within a matter of hours. After further investigation, we’ve found there will be residual impact in that admin status won't get updated or populated to reflect sync completion. We’ve created a secondary fix that fully remediates all aspects of the problem, which is expected to take approximately 48 hours to be fully deployed. We’ll provide an update on Sunday, December 1, 2019, regarding the deployment of the hierarchical solution. Please note that by 3:00 AM on Saturday, November 30, 2019, policy sync is expected to function again, though admin status may not reflect completion. 

Scope of impact: This issue may affect any admins attempting to update and sync policies to their tenant. 

Start time: Tuesday, November 26, 2019, at 11:00 AM UTC

Root cause: A configuration issue is preventing policies set by administrators from syncing. 

Next update by: Sunday, December 1, 2019, at 8:00 PM UTC

Title: Can't sync policies

User Impact: Admins were unable to sync policies to their tenants.

More info: Although the underlying issue was addressed, admins need to manually initiate any policy sync requests that were affected to fully resolve the impact caused by this event.

Final status: We've validated that the fix for the sync policy impact has been fully deployed, and the final fix to address the residual impact to admins that attempt to query the policy sync status through PowerShell has been deployed to over 96 percent of the environment. We estimate that the last fix will complete the deployment to the remaining environment by Monday, December 2, 2019, at 6:00 AM UTC. Due to the majority of customers no longer being affected by this event, we're considering this event as resolved while we monitor the remaining fix deployment to ensure full remediation.

Scope of impact: This issue may have affected any admins attempting to update and sync policies to their tenant.

Start time: Tuesday, November 26, 2019, at 11:00 AM UTC

End time: Sunday, December 1, 2019, at 4:37 AM UTC

Root cause: A configuration issue was preventing policies set by admins from syncing.

Next steps:
- We're assessing our procedures for testing configuration updates to better understand how this issue wasn't caught prior to implementation in order to prevent this issue from reoccurring.
- We're reviewing our monitoring services to look for ways to reduce detection time and more quickly restore service.

This is the final update for the event.

Title: Can't access sites

User Impact: Users may intermittently be unable to access SharePoint Online sites.  

Current status: We're investigating a potential issue and checking for impact to your organization. We'll provide an update within 30 minutes.

Scope of impact: Your organization is affected by this event, and all users attempting to access SharePoint Online sites may be intermittently impacted.

Title: Can't access sites

Current status: We're applying a dynamic throttle that is expected to throttle non-critical tasks and systemically lower utilization. We’re also implementing a configuration change that will allow the affected infrastructure to process additional service load while keeping resources balanced.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Delays or problems loading SharePoint Online sites

User impact: Users may experience intermittent delays or navigation errors when accessing SharePoint sites.

Current Status: We're investigating a potential issue and checking for impact to your organization. We'll provide an update within one hour.

Title: Delays or problems loading SharePoint Online sites

User Impact: Users may experience intermittent delays or navigation errors when accessing SharePoint sites.

Current status: We're reviewing system logs to help determine the source of the issue.

Scope of impact: This issue could potentially affect any of your users intermittently if they are routed through the affected infrastructure.

Next update by: Wednesday, December 11, 2019, at 2:30 AM UTC

Title: Delays or problems loading SharePoint Online sites

User Impact: Users may have experienced intermittent delays or navigation errors when accessing SharePoint sites.

Final status: We reviewed logs and identified that a portion of infrastructure responsible for routing requests was performing below the acceptable thresholds. We rerouted connections and monitored the environment to verify that service was restored.

Scope of impact: This issue could have potentially affected any of your users intermittently if they were routed through the affected infrastructure.

Start time: Wednesday, December 11, 2019, at 12:08 AM UTC

End time: Wednesday, December 11, 2019, at 2:03 AM UTC

Root cause: A portion of infrastructure responsible for routing requests in SharePoint Online was performing below the acceptable thresholds.

Next steps:
-We're reviewing our routing infrastructure to help determine what caused the initial impact to begin and implement ways to prevent similar issues in the future.

This is the final update for the event.

Messages.MessageText:
Title: Can't access Yammer.com

User Impact: Some users may be unable to access the Yammer.com site.

Current status: We've determined that an issue with the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificate for the yammer.com website is resulting in intermittent site access issues. We're investigating the status of the certificate to determine the next steps to restore access to the site for all users. 

Scope of impact: Impact is specific to a subset of your users. 

Start time: Wednesday, November 27, 2019, at 7:13 PM UTC 

Next update by: Wednesday, November 27, 2019, at 9:00 PM UTC

Title: Can't access Yammer.com

User Impact: Some users may have been unable to access the Yammer.com site.

Final status: We determined that the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificate for Yammer had expired. We deployed a new certificate to restore access to Yammer and confirmed with users that the issue is mitigated. 

Scope of impact: Impact was specific to a subset of your users. 

Start time: Wednesday, November 27, 2019, at 7:13 PM UTC 

End time: Wednesday, November 27, 2019, at 8:16 PM UTC 

Root cause: The Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificate for Yammer.com had inadvertently expired, resulting in site access issues. 

Next steps:
We're reviewing out SSL certificate renewal procedures to determine why pending expiration wasn't noticed prior to impact, and to avoid similar impact in the future. 

This is the final update for the event.
